_prev_prog_3.Description:
Process 1 - Silane Transfilling

- Silane processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures (SOP). Employees are

trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- Employees are required to wear standard site PPE which includes flame resistant clothing.

- A visual inspection is required prior to each use to the transfill system. Once the visual

inspection is completed, a leak check is performed using helium. Lastly, a vacuum leak

check is performed.

- Maintenance Team performs preventative maintenance.

- During transfilling, only the required amount of Silane is valved open on the bulk tank to

minimize any potential escape in case of a leak; helps reduce response time on bulk tank.

- Silane system is continuously monitored when in use.

- Emergency shutdown buttons are located near the system in case of an emergency.

- Fire detection/suppression system is in place at the transfill area as well as the bulk source.

- The bulk source is staged in an area with three fire walls.

- The Silane filling system is in a Class 1, Division II room.

- Silane system is shut down and isolated at the end of each workday.

- The Silane system has minimal threaded connections and connections are welded wherever

possible. Piping material is 316L stainless steel and the system incorporates double seal

design which provides the highest leak free integrity.

- Silane transfilling is monitored by both weight and pressure using calibrated scales and

gauges. This cross-reference between weight and pressure minimizes the possibility of an

overfill condition to occur.

- Any changes to the process require a Management of Change, a Process Hazard

Assessment, and potentially a ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 2 - Silane Storage

- Silane processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures (SOP). Employees are

trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- Employees are required to wear standard site PPE which includes flame resistant clothing.

- The Storage of Silane incorporates several preventative actions that ensure safe and leak

free storage.

- A visual inspection of the Silane storage is done on a periodic period, if not daily. Silane

leakage will leave a white or brownish type staining (silicon dioxide powder) when the Silane

comes in contact with air.

- The greatest hazard of Silane is flammable potential. Silane is a pyrophoric gas that burns

upon contact with air. Operators wear personal protective equipment including flame resistant

clothing. Fire detection/suppression systems are in place at bulk source. The bulk source is

staged in an area surrounded on three sides with fire walls.

- Any changes to the storage of Silane require a Management of Change, a Process Hazard

Assessment, and potentially a ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 5- DCS Transfilling

- Dichlorosilane (DCS) processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures (SOP).

- Employees are trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- Employees are required to wear standard site PPE which includes flame resistant clothing.

- A visual inspection is required prior to each use to the transfill system. Once the visual

inspection is complete a leak check is performed using helium. Lastly, a vacuum leak check

is performed.

- Maintenance Team performs preventative maintenance.

- During transfilling, only the required amount of DCS is valved open on the bulk tank to

minimize any potential escape in case of a leak; helps reduce response time on bulk tank.

- DCS system is continuously monitored when in use.

- Emergency shutdown buttons are located near the system in case of an emergency.

- Fire detection/suppression system is in place at the transfill area as well as the bulk source.

- The DCS filling system is in a Class 1, Division II room

- DCS system is shut down and isolated at the end of each workday.

- The DCS system has minimal threaded connections and connections are welded wherever

possible. Piping material is 316L stainless steel and the system incorporates double seal

design which provides the highest leak free integrity.

- DCS transfilling is monitored by both weight and pressure using calibrated scales and

gauges. This cross-reference between weight and pressure minimizes the possibility of an

overfill condition to occur.

- Any changes to the process require a MOC, a Process Hazard Assessment, and potentially a

ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 6- DCS Storage

- Dichlorosilane (DCS) processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures (SOP).

- Employees are trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- A daily inspection of the storage areas is done to check for signs of leaks.

- Monthly Safety Walk includes inspection of storage areas.

- DCS storage locations are stored away from other products for safety purposes.

- Any changes to the process require an MOC, a Process Hazard Assessment, and potentially

a ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 4- HCl Purification

- Hydrogen Chloride (HCl) processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures

(SOP).

- Employees are trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- A visual inspection is required prior to each use to the purification system. Once the visual

inspection is complete a leak check is performed using helium. Lastly, a vacuum leak check

is performed.

- HCl system is shut down and isolated at the end of each workday.

- The HCl system is constructed of 316L Stainless Steel.

- The HCl is monitored by both weight and pressure using calibrated scales and gauges. This

cross-reference between weight and pressure minimizes the possibility of an overfill

condition to occur.

- Any changes to the process require an MOC, a Process Hazard Assessment, and potentially

a ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 3- Hydrogen Chloride Storage

- Hydrogen Chloride (HCl) processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures

(SOP).

- Employees are trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- Employees are required to wear standard site PPE which includes flame resistant clothing.

- A visual inspection of the Hydrogen Chloride storage is done on a periodic period, if not

daily.

- Hydrogen Chloride is a corrosive and a poison. It may explode if heated.

- The Storage of Hydrogen Chloride incorporates several preventative actions that ensure

safe and leak free storage.

- Shed storage areas have fixed monitors.

- Any changes to the process require an MOC, a Process Hazard Assessment, and potentially

a ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 8- Cl2 Purification

- Chlorine (Cl2) processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures (SOP).

- Employees are trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- A visual inspection is required prior to each use to the purification system. Once the visual

inspection is complete a leak check is performed using helium. Lastly, a vacuum leak check

is performed.

- Cl2 system is shut down and isolated at the end of each workday.

- The Cl2 system is constructed of 316L Stainless Steel and connections are welded where

possible.

- Cl2 system is continuously monitored when in use.

- The Cl2 is monitored by both weight and pressure using calibrated scales and gauges. This

cross-reference between weight and pressure minimizes the possibility of an overfill

condition to occur.

- Cl2 system is contained inside of a building which would result in a smaller dispersion

distance should a release ever occur.

- Any changes to the process require an MOC, a Process Hazard Assessment, and potentially

a ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 7- Cl2 Storage

- Chlorine (Cl2) processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures (SOP).

- Employees are trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- A visual inspection of the Chlorine storage is done on a periodic period, if not daily.

- Chlorine is a corrosive, oxidizer and a poison. It may explode if heated.

- Oxidizers and flammables are segregated by 20 feet or a rated fire wall.

- The Storage of Chlorine incorporates several preventative actions that ensure safe and leak

free storage.

- Shed storage areas have fixed monitors.

- Any changes to the process require an MOC, a Process Hazard Assessment, and potentially

a ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 9- BCl3 Transfilling

- Boron Trichloride (BCl3) processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures

(SOP).

- Employees are trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- A visual inspection is required prior to each use to the transfill system. Once the visual

inspection is complete a leak check is performed using helium. Lastly, a vacuum leak check

is performed.

- BCl3 ton room has fixed air monitoring.

- BCl3 system is shut down and isolated at the end of each workday.

- The BCl3 system is constructed of 316L Stainless Steel.

- The BCl3 is monitored by both weight and pressure using calibrated scales and gauges.

This cross-reference between weight and pressure minimizes the possibility of an overfill

condition to occur.

- Any changes to the process require an MOC, a Process Hazard Assessment, and potentially

a ready to operate review (RTOR).

Process 10- BCl3 Storage

- Boron Trichloride (BCl3) processes are covered in site Standard Operating Procedures

(SOP).

- Employees are trained to these SOPs and are re-trained whenever any changes are made.

- A daily inspection of the storage areas is done to check for signs of leaks.

- Monthly BCl3 storage locations are stored away from other products for safety purposes.

- Any changes to the process require an MOC, a Process Hazard Assessment, and potentially

a ready to operate review (RTOR).

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:



Risk Management Plan executive summary to comply with 40 CRF ? 68.155 as amended by [61 FR 31726, June 20, 1996, as amended at 69 FR 18831, Apr. 9, 2004].



Location: Air Liquide Electronics US LP, 19 Steel Road West, Morrisville, PA 19067



THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE:

Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP is committed to: endorsing the principles of Safety First and Zero Accidents, operating safely and reliably in compliance with all applicable laws, performing in an environmentally responsible manner, consistently producing products and services that meet or exceed our customer's expectations, driving continual improvement and innovation & effectively applying lessons learned.



Air Liquide is a member of the American Chemistry Council (ACC) with a commitment to meet all the code requirements of the Responsible Care Program.



The Morrisville plant complies with Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP (ALEUS) policies on process design to reduce probability of release or accident, risk assessment for new and existing processes, incident investigation and reporting, management of change, ready for startup review, preventive maintenance, and training as accidental release prevention.



The Morrisville plant maintains, follows, and trains personnel on an Emergency Action Plan.



Since PHA sections are typically reviewed for possible improvements before a "five year update" is required, it is common to have additional improvements (action items) that are implemented as part of continuous improvement (ex. considerations for facility siting are considered when other changes are proposed for the site). 



THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:



The Air Liquide Morrisville, PA plant primary activity is transfer of product from a bulk source into compressed gas cylinders. This type of activity is commonly referred to as repackaging. The covered processes at the Morrisville Pl

ant are chlorine re-packaging, hydrogen chloride re-packaging,silane re-packaging, boron trichloride repackaging (along with one additional storage locations), and dichlorosilane repackaging (along with two additional storage locations).



THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

The chemical specific accidental release and accident prevention steps are those to mitigate risk from toxic and flammable gases.



This facility complies with EPAs accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. 



Air Liquide Morrisville location utilizes the following accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source:



a) Management of change to ensure the covered process is not altered without a safety review

b) Operation following written operating procedures

c) Training in the process for all operators

d) Preventative maintenance

e) Pre-startup safety review

f) Near miss and incident investigation with corrective and preventative actions

g) Hazard review by process hazard analysis procedure

h) Use of pressure vessels covered under DOT

i) Area electrical classification and conforming equipment

j) Hazard communication (OSHA Hazcomm)

k) Safety program with monthly meetings

l) Hot work program

m) Safe work program



Air Liquide Morrisville location utilizes the following chemical specific prevention steps at the stationary source:

a) Leak checking equipment prior to operation per standard operating procedure

b) Scrubbers to mitigate chemical discharge

c) Pressure relief devices as specified by DOT and/or ASME

d) Hazardous gas monitoring and supervised alarms

e) Process hazard identification by process hazard analysis

f) Check valves 

g) Fire detectors, sprinklers and alarms

h) Operating by following written operating procedures

i) Emergency action plan training

j) Operating and maintenance training

k) Management of c

hange for all changes

l) Lockout followed (safe work program)

m) Burst disc

n) Ventilation

o) Preventative maintenance

p) Pressure gauges

q) Housekeeping

r) Personal protective equipment



THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



Air Liquide Morrisville location has never had an accident involving chlorine, hydrogen chloride, silane, boron trichloride or dichlorosilane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place.



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM: 



The Morrisville location maintains its own team of emergency responders to handle emergencies involving chemical release.  At the plant, a stand alone building has been designated as a command post center where ER equipment is stored and emergencies can be managed. The building also contains the key contact information to communicate to outside agencies and local authorities.  The Emergency Response Team members have completed their initial 40 hour training requirement and also receive their annual required 8 hour refresher training.   Plant communicates with the Bucks County Emergency Management, the Bucks County LEPC and the Morrisville Fire Department. 



The Morrisville Plant maintains a facility Emergency Action Plan that has been shared with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The plan details the essential actions to take should an emergency occur.    Plant personnel conduct periodic drills. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



As is our policy at Air Liquide, we continue to review our process(es) for possible improvements to the process and to the operational methods and to evaluate new technology to lower risk. Air Liquide Morrisville, PA, conducts and resolves all findings from its PHA and other hazard analysis and utilizes a Management of Change Program to evaluate proposed changes prior to implementation. For example, Morrisville plans on 

1) Increasing labeling of process piping; and, 

2) Reviewing and revising the facility mecha
